abstract.p: Letter from Adrienne Germain, president of International Women's Health Coalition, comments on August 20 article on Nigeria's struggle to effect economic and political reforms

block.p: Re ''Against Tough Odds, Nigeria Bets on Reform'' (front page, Aug. 20): Nigeria is in grave peril from H.I.V. and AIDS. The H.I.V. infection rate is relatively low, an estimated 5 percent compared with 20 percent in South Africa. So Nigeria still has a chance to prevent catastrophe.
The key is to empower the country's 26 million adolescents, aged 10 to 19, by providing the information and services, education and employment opportunities they need to avoid risky sex.

Re ''Against Tough Odds, Nigeria Bets on Reform'' (front page, Aug. 20): Nigeria is in grave peril from H.I.V. and AIDS. The H.I.V. infection rate is relatively low, an estimated 5 percent compared with 20 percent in South Africa. So Nigeria still has a chance to prevent catastrophe.
The key is to empower the country's 26 million adolescents, aged 10 to 19, by providing the information and services, education and employment opportunities they need to avoid risky sex.

The United States should do all it can to support this generation of Nigerians, especially the girls. If we don't, as Prof. Ibironke Akinsete, the chairwoman of Nigeria's National Action Committee on AIDS, has said, ''we will not have a next generation.''
ADRIENNE GERMAIN President, International Women's Health Coalition New York, Aug. 22, 2000
